awd_titl_txt: Multidimensional Support to Increase Retention of Physics Majors
awd_abstract_narration:
This significant project will provide at least 60 scholarships to financially eligible and academically meritorious students at the University of California, Irvine (UCI) who are majoring in physics. UCI is a leader in serving low-income, first-generation, and underrepresented students and recently the number of incoming physics majors has doubled. However, the rate of retention has remained low as admissions have grown. This project will provide scholarships, strengthen the departmental student community, increase academic support through faculty advising and access to tutoring in gateway courses, and encourage research and industry opportunities to combat this trend.
 
The S-STEM Physics Scholars Program aims to double the number of students who graduate with a physics degree, increase the graduation rate of low-income students to 75%, and improve physics major academic success in introductory physics and mathematics courses. This work will contribute to understanding of student experience and outcomes due to interventions targeted to increase student retention, particularly of low-income and first-generation students. The research conducted under this project will have a major impact on the extent and ways that Physics Education is implemented and supported at UCI, have implications for undergraduate STEM program design and instruction, and make contributions to foundational knowledge and theory regarding college persistence in STEM fields. This research includes surveys and other quantitative measures as well as qualitative interviews from students, faculty and other stakeholders. Research questions center upon persistence, attitudes towards science, and changes in students' physics identity. The project will partner with the Statistical Research Center of the American Institute of Physics to ensure the proper evaluation of benchmarks and other student outcomes and experiences as well as the dissemination of best practices to a national audience.

por.por_cntn:
This project instituted the following reforms to improve success and retention of physics and applied physics majors at the University of California, Irvine:

  1. Create scholarships for low-income physics and applied physics majors
  2. Expand peer mentoring & encourage research and industry opportunities
  3. Implement a new faculty advising structure
  4. Offer scholarships to the campus tutoring program (LARC) for lower-division, gateway courses critical to success in the physics major

We report on our success in each of these goals.

Create scholarships for low-income physics and applied physics majors

We provided over 99 scholarship-years of support -- well over the 60 originally planned -- to 37 physics and applied physics majors between 2017 and 2024. Of our former scholars, 87% graduated with degrees in physics or applied physics from UCI, 6% graduated with a physics degree from other universities, 3% transferred out of STEM, and 3% are in progress towards finishing their degree at UCI.

Expand peer mentoring & encourage research and industry opportunities

In 2018-19, we designed and deployed a new peer mentoring program for incoming physics and applied physics majors. Starting in 2019-20, this program became part of a course assigned by default to incoming physics and applied physics majors. This increased the number of incoming students we mentor to be about ⅔ of the incoming class. The peer mentoring program remains active, and in the most recent academic year included 36 continuing undergraduate student mentors.

A key aspect of the peer mentoring curriculum is research and internship talks given by continuing students describing their experiences, important skills they have learned, and how to get involved in research. 

Implement a new faculty advising structure & research application process

We began our updates to advising in 2017 by redesigning the undergraduate portion of the department website to include answers to commonly-asked questions. In this way, we could better serve our growing number of majors by making it easier to find answers to their own questions and then focus time with faculty advisors on deeper issues. Between 2018 and 2022, we began delivering faculty advising in group workshops in which students could both ask faculty questions and discuss the curriculum and course planning with other peers. In 2022, we further updated our online advising curriculum to include self-service videos describing overall course planning and each concentration choice. We also deployed a research portal that allows faculty to post research opportunities and students to apply in a streamlined system.

Offer scholarships to the campus tutoring program (LARC) for lower-division, gateway courses critical to success in the physics major

We provided scholarships as intended to financially-eligible students in lower-division gateway physics and math courses. Beyond this original project goal, we expanded academic support to include students in upper-division physics classes. This support, administered by the campus tutoring program, provided a trained tutor who held workshops on key areas of difficulty in introductory physics and math throughout the academic year. The tutor also provides weekly drop-in office hours. As of the close of this grant, the campus tutoring office continued these offerings.

Research and measurement

We completed seven years of survey data collection covering physics majors' attitudes, reports on departmental activities, and experience. We also conducted focus groups of physics majors and developed a codebook for the themes observed in the focus groups that relate to both the physics student experience and family engagement. While we made substantial progress towards these efforts, additional analysis is needed to finalize the findings.
